results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander (Alex) Nicoll (1898–1968) grew up in Princes Hill in Melbourne.

As a young man, and after working in various capacities, Alex met wealthy business owner Arthur Thomas who assisted him into business running an import agency at Tasmania House in Flinders Lane. Alex would enjoy a lifelong involvement with Melbourne’s ‘rag trade’ (clothing business) in Flinders Lane, including serving for some years as the President of the Victorian Softgoods Association.

In the 1930s Alex inherited an Agfa 16mm camera, projector and collapsible screen from Arthur Thomas who had been a keen photographer, and over the 1940s and 1950s would capture wonderful moments around Melbourne such as the celebrations for the 1956 Olympics and visits to the beaches of Port Phillip Bay.

After Alexander died, his son Mac continued the family filming enthusiasm in the 1960s and 1970s. Around 2005, the Nicoll family decided to donate most of their collection of films to ACMI.

This reel captures a military parade likely to be sometime in the 1940s down Alexandra Parade, Moonee Ponds and some garden views.

Selected highlight list:

00:00:00:05 a crowd lines the street (most likely Mt Alexander Road near Moonee Ponds Town Hall, the family lived in Essendon)
00:00:00:28 soldiers parade down the street before a crowd of onlookers
00:00:00:51 parade passes a dais on which people stand, one in a mayoral robe and chain of office
00:01:12:00 military trucks and equipment can be seen in the parade
00:01:38:00 soldiers relaxing on the lawn with members of the crowd after the parade

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

results.title: [Remix: Transport]
results.brief_description: This short film is a remix of archival footage from the ACMI Collection, focusing on public transport in Victoria. The remix contains footage of trams, trains, Flinders Street Station and city streets in Melbourne.

results.title: 'Moomba' Festival 1967 - 'Float parade' thru' the city.
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a cultural public event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Monarch royals who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film shows footage of the 1967 Moomba parade, filmed from the intersection of Victoria and Swanston Street at the top end of the city. The photographer captures stunning colour footage of the parade as it rounds the corner leading through the city to the Shrine of Remembrance, with crowds of onlookers lining the streets.

The parade is led by a marching band, the inaugural King of Moomba Robert Morley, and the Queen of Moomba, Patsy Earp, on a large, swan-shaped float. The camera then follows the various decorated floats, performers, clowns and celebrities, including Noel Ferrier and Mary Hardy, the National Trust, the Lions Club, Retails Traders of Victoria, and Lionel Rose in a red convertible car (including a close-up of Rose waving at the camera).

The footage then appears to shift to the 1968 Moomba parade, with the Queen of Moomba Judy Fenelon, followed by signs reading Moomba’s 14th Birthday, and the King of Moomba Alfred Marks. Some of the notable floats in this sequence include Myer Department Store, Hansel and Gretel, Geraldine O’Shea Academy of Irish Dancing, Gravox, the Ettamogah Pub, and Crawford Productions.

Content warning: this footage includes a short clip of clowns Zig (Jack Perry) and Zag (Douglas McKenzie) performing in the parade. In 1994, Perry was convicted of sexually assaulting his granddaughter 20 years earlier, and in 1999 Zig and Zag were dethroned from their position as Moomba Monarchs.

results.title: 'Moomba' 1972 - 'Float parade' thru' the city.
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a public cultural event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Moomba monarchs who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film features footage of the 1972 Moomba parade. Filmed at the intersection of Victoria and Swanston Street, opposite the City Baths, the camera follows the parade on its path through the city towards the Shrine of Remembrance.

That year’s Queen of Moomba, Debra Scott, leads the parade on a large decorative float with a white swan at the forefront, seated on a throne of pink petals. The parade then follows, including entertainers, celebrities and decorated floats on flat-bed trucks and cars, showcasing businesses and community groups. Some of the notable floats include Philippine Airlines, Kyneton Historical Centre, Gemini 12, Warburton Tourist Attractions, Theatres of Moscow, the Gold Coast, and a Chinese dragon dance. Towards the end of the parade, the King of Moomba John Farnham appears in a purple velvet suit seated in a horse-drawn carriage.

Content warning: this film includes brief footage of clown Zig (Jack Perry) in the parade, wearing blackface clown make-up. In 1994 Perry was convicted of sexually assaulting his granddaughter 20 years earlier, and in 1999 Zig and Zag were dethroned from their position as Moomba Monarchs.

results.title: 'Moomba' 1973 - 'Float parade' thru' the city
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a public cultural event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Moomba monarchs who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film shows footage of the 1973 Moomba parade at the intersection of Victoria and Swanston Streets and captures the parade and crowds of onlookers as it passes through the city.

At the beginning of the film we see the 1973 King of Moomba, Sir Doug Nicholls (Yorta Yorta, 1906 – 1988), waving to the crowd from the back of a car, followed by the Queen of Moomba, Janice Bridgeford. Sir Doug Nicholls was a celebrated football player, pastor, and activist for First Peoples rights, and one of the founders of the Federal Council for Aboriginal Advancement (later the Federal Council for the Advancement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders). He became Governor of South Australia in 1976 and was knighted in 1977.

The camera then follows the procession of floats, dancers, baton twirlers, stilt walkers, clowns, and other entertainers as they pass through the crowds of people down Swanston Street. Notable floats include the Wizard of Oz, Malta Travel Service, Clarke Mobile Cranes, Four’nTwenty Pies and ATV0, ‘Australia’s Action Station’.

Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Moomba monarchs who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film shows footage of the 1973 Moomba parade at the intersection of Victoria and Swanston Streets and captures the parade and crowds of onlookers as it passes through the city.

At the beginning of the film we see the 1973 King of Moomba, Sir Doug Nicholls (Yorta Yorta, 1906 – 1988), waving to the crowd from the back of a car, followed by the Queen of Moomba, Janice Bridgeford. Sir Doug Nicholls was a celebrated football player, pastor, and activist for First Peoples rights, and one of the founders of the Federal Council for Aboriginal Advancement (later the Federal Council for the Advancement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders). He became Governor of South Australia in 1976 and was knighted in 1977.

The camera then follows the procession of floats, dancers, baton twirlers, stilt walkers, clowns, and other entertainers as they pass through the crowds of people down Swanston Street. Notable floats include the Wizard of Oz, Malta Travel Service, Clarke Mobile Cranes, Four’nTwenty Pies and ATV0, ‘Australia’s Action Station’.

results.title: 'Moomba' 1974 - 'Float parade' thru' the city
results.brief_description:
The Pallaris Collection contains 16mm colour footage of the Moomba parades in Melbourne from the 1950s to 1970s. Most films were shot by aspiring filmmaker John Christofi Pallaris, while some are credited to Reg Robinson.

Moomba Festival held its inaugural event through the streets and parks of Melbourne on 12 March 1955. The festival was designed as a public cultural event for the city, incorporating a street parade, a carnival and an outdoor art show, among other festivities. Throughout the 1950s to 1970s the grand parade down Swanston Street was at its peak, attracting crowds of hundreds of thousands of people and featuring a stream of decorated floats on flat-bed trucks advertising businesses and community groups, accompanied by marching bands, celebrities, clowns, and performers on stilts. The crowning of Monarch royals who lead the parade has been a tradition since 1955.

This 16mm film shows footage of the 1974 Moomba parade through Melbourne, filmed at the corner of Victoria and Swanston Streets, opposite the City Baths. The parade begins with a marching band, followed by Disney cartoon characters Captain Hook and Mr Smee from Peter Pan, and Goofy. The 1974 Queen of Moomba Marianne Perrott appears on a decorative blue float, seated in a throne behind the distinctive white swan.

The camera then follows the rest of the parade, featuring entertainers, celebrities and characters such as Humphrey B. Bear, Daryl Somers and Ossie Ostrich, and a particularly impressive display of decorated floats and performances. Some of the notable appearances include Waltons department store, a group of Michelin men, the new Holden Torana with a sign reading “just in time for Moomba”, ATV0 ‘Australia’s Action Station’, Bendigo Pottery featuring a potter making ceramics on a wheel, Jewel Box, the Royal Children’s Hospital Pied Pipers, a Ukrainian Easter float, a Chinese dragon dance, Whittlesea District Mini Bike Club, and the Hungarian Square Dancing Association.

results.title: Don't Shoot the Messenger
results.brief_description: “Visuals recorded live at a digital meditation in cyberspace performed during the Mayday dance party 1993. A series of computers and cameras were interconnected, manipulated realtime and projected.” Sourced from VHS cover slip for Don’t Shoot the Messenger

results.title: Wildcats and Pipedreams
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Film & Television, John Richardson and David Greig
results.brief_description: Wildcats and Pipedreams follows the crew of an oil drilling rig in the Timor Sea. It gives a fascinating insight into the lives of people living and working in a remote and difficult environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kestrel Film & Television, John Richardson and David Greig

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, titled ‘Just Roaming’, Ted tells the story of a road trip through Victoria. The Parsons travel through Mount Hotham and Myrtleford, down to Melbourne and then back through Bairnsdale and Paynesville on the south coast.

A feature is the footage of the Gliding Club of Victoria, including female pilots, and historic buildings in Melbourne such as the Shrine of Remembrance and Ormond College at the University of Melbourne. There are beautiful scenes of the Victorian countryside throughout.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘E.J. Parsons Presents’, ‘Just Roaming’
00:00:11:00 a 1950s car leaves the driveway of a brick house and drives down a country road
00:00:35:00 flooded roads and paddocks, uprooted trees in the river
00:01:30:00 a visit to the Hume Dam (formerly known as the Hume Weir) including scenes of Lake Hume
00:02:55:00 man with binoculars, looking out to snow covered mountains
00:03:28:00 two women and a man playing with snowballs
00:04:27:00 a man and woman wade through the snow; woman playfully flashing her underwear to the camera
00:04:50:00 snowy countryside
00:06:33:00 the Hotham Heights Hotel in Mount Hotham, with guests on the balcony looking out over the railings
00:06:51:00 bleached white gum trees and yellow buttercups
00:07:33:00 beautiful views across the mountain ranges
00:08:59:00 a clock tower
00:09:18:00 road sign ‘Myrtleford Please Slow Down’
00:09:27:00 a helicoptor landing in a field, followed by footage of gliders taking off and landing
00:10:27:00 logo ‘Gliding Club of Vict.’ on a wing
00:10:33:00 two young men seated in a glider, smiling and waving at the camera
00:10:59:00 a yellow glider taking off
00:11:19:00 young woman in a glider
00:11:57:00 gardens
00:13:14:00 bridge over the Yarra River, Melbourne, with a church spire in the background
00:13:33:00 the Shrine of Remembrance, Melbourne
00:14:18:00 boys in a red row boat on the Yarra
00:14:25:00 Ormond College, University of Melbourne
00:14:38:00 flowers
00:16:11:00 feeding the seagulls at the beach
00:17:16:00 farm paddocks
00:17:28:00 scenic shot of three people on a rocky outcrop
00:17:43:00 sign for ‘Bairnsdale Please Slow Down’ followed by scenes in the country town
00:18:22:00 a unicycle mounted on a white brick wall
00:18:29:00 the Technical School, Bairnsdale
00:20:34:00 road sign ‘Paynesville Please Slow Down’
00:20:55:00 two women walking along the beach
00:21:32:00 view from a boat on the river
00:22:52:00 boat named ‘Krunulla’
00:24:05:00 poplar and pine trees
00:27:09:00 title card ‘Springtime’ followed by scenery in country and footage of farm animals
